item.title: Home
item.content:encoded:
This is what I think…

Hello there!

I'm Janos Szlatenyi ['jɑni slɑ'tɛnji] , but please, call me Jani. It is easier for both of us. Welcome to my personal website.

This site is a space for me to organize my thoughts, process my frustrations, and explore ideas that capture my interest. It serves as a tool for self-reflection and personal growth, allowing me to crystalize my thinking through the act of writing.

Here, you'll find a collection of my musings, reflections, and explorations. Some may be raw and unfiltered, others more polished and refined. But all of them represent a piece of my journey, a snapshot of my mental landscape at a given moment in time.

While this site is primarily for my own benefit, I welcome you to explore it if you wish. Perhaps in my words, you'll find something that resonates with your own experiences, or gain a new perspective on a familiar topic.

Thank you for visiting,

Jani

item.title: About
item.content:encoded:
Honest self-definition is very difficult, if not impossible. Whether intentionally or subconsciously, we try to influence how others perceive us based on how we want to think about ourselves or how we want others to think about us. This self-image is much less solid and sound than one might imagine. Our self-image is far more volatile than we realize, depending on our mood, the target audience, and the goal we want to achieve with the introduction.

Asking yourself "Who am I really?" in a closed room where you want to answer to yourself - where you are your own judge, jury, defender, and prosecutor at the same time - that's called therapy. It's supervised and run by professionals for a reason.

I've decided to write in two different personas. Below, you'll find my "LinkedIn-style" introduction, with vague and flashy short statements (on the left), and a "bar translator" version of how I would describe it in a bar after a couple of beers to a friend of a friend who I've just been introduced to (on the right). 

LinkedIn

Hungarian born resourceful economist and finance expert with strong IT background and polymathic tendencies.

Extensive leadership and management experience.

Tipsy (Bar) Translator

So, I was born in Hungary during the communism. Initially, I wanted to be a biochemist, but I discovered there was no faculty of biochemistry in my country at that time - only chemistry with a specialization in biology. I didn't want to pursue that path.

On the other hand, I got my first computer in 1985 and spent my adolescence hacking, coding, and playing on various computers. I attended a math-intensive high school and had the opportunity to earn a college degree in IT after graduation with just one extra year of study. 

Nevertheless, I still wanted to pursue a regular degree afterwards, feeling that IT alone wouldn't be sufficient for me. My parents were well-renowned economists, and following this family heritage, I developed an interest in management science (from my mother), finance (from my stepfather), and cognitive psychology and philosophy (from my father).

My brain is like a sponge, I remember the text of my 1st grader public speaking context, I play the piano, I can do origami, you name it, I’m surprisingly versatile. (I mean surprisingly for other people usually). Accordingly people usually find me entertaining and interesting. (and of course I can be a real asshole if I’m bored or annoyed usually by ignorance, malevolence or stupidity). I also like movies, do you want to talk about movies? 

I've been doing this shit for almost 20 years, man. I've hired a lot of people and fought a lot of battles. But I've always been better at hiring good people than claiming credit for their work. I'm much better at managing down than up. I think my teams generally liked me, and it was great to see junior analysts grow into smart, mature senior leaders or experts. I've never really cared what my management thought or wanted; as long as the business and clients were happy, and I felt I was doing something meaningful, something I could be proud of, I was satisfied. 

Out of the box thinker.

More to come…

Many people find me weird. I have a deep voice, a strong accent. I usually tell people that if in my childhood somebody tells me that the W is called double U on English for a reason, and it has nothing to do with the letter V - on Hungarian W is called double V - I would not have problem today ordering a glass of water today.

Since my young adulthood I was never the smartest in my environment, but I was always acknowledged and respected to be smart. Just like I was never the best athlete in anything, but I was better in everything than the vast majority. And I tried a lot of things and I was interested in everything. Once my primary schoolmate said, that today I would be given medication for hyperactive, ADHD symptoms, and I was lucky that at that time these were not available conditions. She might had a point. My parents decided to keep me busy, not that I needed too much pushing. Maybe, sometimes for the piano. 

I like solving problems and doing stuff that has some product. This involves heavy experimentation with pretty much everything. If there is a room, and there is a button, at some point I will push it. My favorite toy was Lego.

People also said that I’m resourceful. I’m good with tools. I’m very creative. (sometimes funny)

But I don’t know, I don’t really think about this, I think about this at the moment. Do you want to talk about it?

More to come…

item.title: The Shed Project
item.content:encoded:
I stopped working about a month ago—or rather, I should say I stopped being employed. We agreed that I no longer wanted to continue, as 15 years was enough. I spent the majority of my professional career at that company. Over 15 years, you learn a lot: who the players are, what the game is. You start liking both the players and the game. But with time, things change. You change, grow, and sometimes burn out. The company changes, the world changes, and you start hating the game, eventually even the players too—not necessarily on a personal level, but on a phenomenological or role-based level.

Before I start a new position somewhere, I really need a break. I've built up significant frustration, along with valuable experience and knowledge that I need to process, organize, and let settle. I need to let these crystallize, or I'll just carry them forward as chaotic ripples of both frustrations and experiences, rather than their core essence that I can build upon later. This website is also just a tool to facilitate this process.

In the last couple of years, I've developed a hunger for a project with a material, substantial outcome—one that finishes on time and within budget, with the final product having both functional and preferably aesthetic value. Yes, code, APIs, and databases can have aesthetic value, just like vases, paintings, and chaise lounges. But I decided to demolish the old shed and build a new one instead. I've built enough of the previously mentioned ones. Some of them I'm even proud of, and I wanted to be proud again of something I completed. A real thing, not a senior-level presentation that "goes really well"—where besides everybody feeling good and important, nothing really happens—or a LinkedIn post bragging about some six-of-one, half-dozen-of-the-other achievements where the act of showing off is as important as, or even more important than, the achievement itself.

I detailed the steps for myself and assigned a rough timeline:

  • Timeline and Tasks:

    Week 1:

    • Design, material research, and planning

    • Permit/Legal research

    • Demolition of the old shed

    • Ground work, ensuring drainage

    Week 2:

    • Foundation

    • Structural work

    • Begin build-up

    Week 3:

    • Complete build-up

    • Sealing/weather proofing/Painting/Treating

    Week 4:

    • Roofing

    • Electronics installation

    • Water system installation

    • Ground work, fix up surroundings

    • Final cleanup

Budget Considerations:

I've set up a budget based on my research. For the baseline, I used shed-kit prices:

  • A similarly sized redwood shed-kit costs between $4,000 and $6,000, plus an additional $1,000-$2,000 for foundation work.

  • Better prefab epoxy sheds are sold in the $2,000-$3,000 range.

However, when considering a custom-built solution with:

  • Non-traditional framed structure

  • Custom-made components

  • Redwood/high quality wood construction

  • Nice structural elements

  • Solid waterproofing and drainage

  • Self-sustaining solar and battery solution for lighting

  • Irrigation system for surroundings

The price point quickly jumps to the $10,000+ range. With quality materials and labor, it can easily reach $20,000 or more.

Given these factors, my original target budget was $10,000 for materials, with the intention to reuse things I already had.

The old shed and researching the new

The old shed was in a hazardous condition. It almost collapsed on me once, and we hadn't stored anything important in it for a while. Upon investigation of its instability, I was surprised to find that the structure was essentially held together by only six 4-inch nails and the roof structure. The foundation was non-existent. It was built on 6 pits filled with bricks and concrete. It had sunk over time, critters had moved in, and gophers had hoarded dirt under the foundation, elevating the ground level. As a result, the wooden foundation structure was almost fully disintegrated. Even the OSB sheets that served as the floor were severely damaged.

As a homeowner, I've extensively investigated various building codes: California state codes, county-specific regulations, and city-specific rules where I live. This research has been a bizarre experience, but also very useful knowledge. The main benefits of this research are understanding where you might unintentionally violate code and knowing what arguments you can use if anyone raises concerns about your project.

(Did you know, based on the 2022 California Resident Code -CRC-, you do need permit for a fence bigger than 7 feet, but you can build an oil rig in your backyard without local permit, assuming you keep the setback rules of to the property line, and you own mineral rights on your property. No kidding.)

I quickly figured out that I didn't need a permit. If I had kept the original placement and sizing, I could have even argued that I was just "repairing" because it was a safety hazard. However, I didn't want to keep the old footprint, mainly because the offset from the fence was under 1 foot, and I wanted to keep a slightly bigger space between the fence and the new shed. Not the 5 feet as per the code, but at least 2 feet. You can do 3 feet if you comply with fire safety, height, and other limitations, but I just kept it between 2 and 3. 

For the design, I made numerous sketches, though I'm not very good at drawing. I also made basic calculations about the maximum load and the forces on important structural points. I researched the soil type and determined what foundation I wanted to build. After all this, I settled on a simple structure: four corner poles holding two beams at different heights, connecting them with a sloped lean-to roof, and a preferably sliding door on the shorter side of the structure.

Another key element in my design was a 99-inch long double-pane sliding window, a leftover from the house remodel that I wanted to incorporate. I realized this window could serve multiple purposes. With the sliding door occupying one half of the shorter side wall, the window would nicely give a feeling of extended space to the fairly small shed. This was particularly beneficial since the shed is too narrow to meaningfully shelf-up both walls anyway.

The addition of the window not only solved a practical issue but also promised to enhance the overall aesthetics and functionality of the space. It would allow natural light to flood in, making the interior feel more open and connected to the outside.

With these elements in place - the basic structure, the sliding door, and the repurposed window - my plan was fully formed. Excited to bring this vision to life, I began ordering the necessary materials and preparing the site for construction.

The foundation and groundwork

Foundation Work: The Most Important and Least Visible Component

Ideally, I should have done a concrete pad, but creating a 6'x10' proper concrete foundation would have been a disproportionate amount of work if I couldn't order the concrete and had to mix and pour it myself. Since the lot has a slight grade, I decided instead to build retaining walls. These walls serve multiple purposes:

  1. Hide the foundation

  2. Steer water flow away from the base of the structure

  3. Provide depth to work with in building a strong enough base

Our soil is very clay-heavy and we have many gophers. My main concerns were:

  1. Preventing gophers from pushing up dirt under the foundation

  2. Keeping critters from nesting under the structure

  3. Preventing wet clay from the soil from "filling up" the base

  4. Solving drainage for any water that might go under the shed

  5. Ensuring the foundation is strong enough to hold a quadruple load compared to standard sheds (80 lb/ft instead of the standard 20 lb/ft)

The target maximum load was set to 5000 lbs. To meet these requirements, I decided to build on 9 concrete piers. Each pier:

  • Stands on a 2'x2' pad, 2 inches deep

  • Has a 6-inch compacted mixed gravel base underneath the pad

This setup should be good for up to 9000 lbs., even in the rainy season when the soil is more moist. The base is covered with a 1/2-inch galvanized metal wire mesh and a water barrier membrane. The pit is filled with crushed rock. The wire mesh loops up on all sides and is fixed to the base frame structure.

The base frame is constructed from 2"x10" pressure-treated lumber. To ensure structural integrity, joints are reinforced with metal plating, and 12" structural screws are used, particularly at the corners where most of the load will be carried.

An important lesson learned: I made a 2-inch error in the diagonal measurement. This mistake would prove significant later in the project. It highlighted a crucial principle in construction:

Always check every diagonal at every step of the work, multiple times, when building anything rectangular.

This experience underscored a fundamental truth about carpentry. The core skills of carpentry are consistently cutting precise lengths and accurately measuring 90-degree angles. In essence, every tool can be viewed as a variation of a chisel, and every angle as a perpendicular if you examine closely enough. All other aspects of carpentry are variations on these basic principles.

The Structure

For the flooring, I chose to use 25/32" sturdy floor panels with a water membrane applied to the connections and edges. The primary purpose of this membrane is to prevent moisture buildup at horizontal wood-to-wood connections.

The main structural elements consist of 6"x6" redwood poles and 12' long, 2"x10" LVL (laminated veneer lumber) polylam treated engineered wood beams. I used two of these beams fixed together for added strength. For aesthetic and practical purposes, both the front and back beams are designed to appear as if constructed from three planks, though in reality, there are only two. The front beam received an extra attachment on the overhanging parts, while the back beam is hollow in the middle section. This design choice significantly eased the handling of the weight during solo construction.

The wood-LVL (laminate composite) beams offer numerous advantages, with the most crucial for my project being their resistance to deflection, twisting, bowing, and cupping. Given that the entire structure relies heavily on these beams and poles, and one side is almost entirely a single window, it was essential to choose a wood product that not only fits the concept but also provides sufficient structural stability. This choice ensures I won't have to worry about potential tension issues caused by deflection in the future.

I wanted to create an exposed frame, inspired by the oriental style buildings prevalent in our area with strong Asian influence. The 2-inch diagonal error in the base necessitated individual measurement and cutting of each piece, which presented an opportunity to play with perspectives.

Given the shed's long and tall dimensions, I made two key adjustments:

  1. From my house, I aimed to make the shed appear longer, emphasizing the separation between the home and the deep backyard. Conversely, from the neighbor's window, I wanted it to look shorter.

  2. I wanted to reduce the perceived height and direct attention to the header part of the shed.

To achieve these effects, I implemented several design choices:

  • The spacing of poles on the longer side is unequal, with the space between poles shrinking from my perspective and growing from my neighbor's viewpoint.

  • The window on the other side is not centered.

  • Equally spaced rafters strengthen the illusion of the non-equally divided sections, also makes the header more “busy”, acts as an eye-candy. 

  • On the sides, the lower 6-inch plank goes behind the poles, while the upper 4-inch plank goes in front, both carpentered. This creates an outward-leaning illusion, directing eyes upward and giving the impression of a shorter building.

These design decisions were made to manifest architectural beauty beyond simple aesthetics, yet not quite reaching true architecture. I kept in mind four aspects of architectural beauty:

  1. Beauty of proportions

  2. Beauty of symmetry

  3. Beauty of variability

  4. Beauty of stability

Proportions and symmetry create harmony, variability generates interest, and stability is an explicit virtue in architecture, even when serving only ornamental functions. For instance, the 6x10 floor and 8x12 roof nearly achieve a golden ratio. The sliding door's middle cross plank is ornamental, providing continuity and symmetry with the non-sliding-door section. The side poles, while not structural, create an illusion of stability and break up the optics of a plain wall. Large black structural iron ties mimic the joints beneath them, highlighting structural stability through color contrast.

These patterns repeat around the shed in various sizes, materials, and forms. A hidden downward-pointed wall light behind the upper cross plank aims to bring the roof optically lower while providing ambient light and further highlighting the contrast between the redwood and the blue/gray panels with black structural iron ties.

Next steps

Currently, the shed operates on a 1KW camping battery and has no water connection. The next steps in the project are:

  1. Connect the shed to the 300-gallon rainwater barrel and pump.

  2. Put solar panels to the roof and build out the electrical system, including the battery, charge controller, and inverter.

  3. Install gutters and connect them to the rainwater barrel.

  4. Add a standing bicycle storage unit at the end of the wall.

  5. Complete the paving and landscaping around the building.

These additions will enhance the shed's functionality, making it more self-sufficient and integrated with its surroundings. The rainwater collection system and solar power setup will significantly improve its eco-friendliness and utility, providing a nice storage unit to the previously built planting table.

This project has been an enjoyable and rewarding experience. It has allowed me to combine practical construction skills with creative design elements, resulting in a structure I can be proud of. The process of planning, problem-solving, and seeing the shed come to life has been particularly rewarding. I believed I can do it, so I did it.

Now let's find a job and hope that the challenges I'll be paid to solve will bring at least a fraction of the same satisfaction.

item.title: I want to talk about data quality!
item.content:encoded:
I'm shocked and frustrated when I hear people discuss data quality issues and checks, especially when these same individuals don't listen to explanations about the challenges of applying uniform statements and seemingly universal rules and standards to data quality. This is particularly problematic in paradigms where shared services attempt to serve multiple applications and use cases with the same content but for different purposes, or when an organization begins handling various data sources and tries to unify them for a common use case.

To truly understand and ensure data quality, extensive collaboration is required, along with general and business-specific knowledge. This includes understanding the product, the business and supplier chains, and, crucially, what the client aims to achieve from a holistic perspective. Ironically, this comprehensive view is often disregarded by the very people who claim to prioritize data quality.

While everyone claims to be client-centric, this focus tends to be limited to their own boundaries and organizations, failing to consider the broader implications and interconnections of data quality across different contexts.

The word "quality" originates from the Latin word "qualis," meaning "of what kind." The Cambridge Dictionary defines it as "how good or bad something or someone is." However, perhaps the most accurate definition is: "The property of something or someone that describes how well they fulfill the requirements set for them." . In other words:

"The quality of something is how well it fits its purpose"

consequently:

  1. There is no quality without purpose.

  2. The level of understanding about the purpose of something defines the capability to ensure its quality.

1. The quality of this shoe is amazing

When someone describes the quality of an object, they're not discussing the object itself; objects have no intrinsic quality. Assessing the quality of a shoe, for instance, assumes a shared understanding of its use and our expectations for it. Quality assurance means vastly different things for a beach flip-flop versus an astronaut's boots.

Our unspoken, mutual expectation is that a shoe should be comfortable, protect our feet and toes, and allow easy movement. We also expect durability, good quality materials (consider what "quality" means in this context), and manufacturing precision to ensure longevity. The shoe's quality exists only because we have a collective idea of what constitutes a good-quality shoe; we understand its purpose and use.

If I mention buying good-quality hiking boots, most people can envision what that means, even if they've never hiked. They have expectations and ideas about how hiking shoes differ from rain boots or high heels.

Quality, therefore, is not an intrinsic property. It belongs more to the user and observer, and their general ideas and expectations about the product, rather than to the producer or provider and their efforts to improve "quality."

2. The quality of this data is amazing

While I intend to discuss Knuth and Wirth's different interpretations of data, information, and knowledge more extensively in the future, for now, let me establish some definitions, carefully avoiding an explanation of "knowledge". I'll use an arbitrary definition based on my understanding:

  • Data is simply observed (and recorded) information

  • Information is a substance that creates a unique mapping between mutually agreed signals and(/or) signal systems.

The first statement is fairly straightforward. The second packs in several concepts. In scientific terms, "substance" is a way of saying "thing" or "stuff" without delving into deeper analysis of discrete existence, uniformity, or atomicity. Let's accept that substance means: it is some thing.

I avoid using Knuth's definition—as he provided many—but his argument distinguishing data from information revolves around data's "meaning" and attempts to capture the "knowledge" needed to connect fact (data) with meaning (information). In my definition above, meaning is neatly hidden within the phrase "mutually agreed signal systems" and the act of mapping.

The existence of data assumes there is information to be captured. The existence of information assumes an underlying mutual agreement over some signals or signal systems. In Knuth's language, we know what a fact (data) means (we are informed by it) because we have knowledge that aids interpretation.

What does this pseudo-academic/scientific/philosophical discourse have to do with quality?

Based on our two sets of definitions, I argue that data itself cannot have quality, but the level of how well the information is understood does. If quality is fitness for purpose, and data is observed information where information defines data's meaning, then quality is a function of the level of understanding of the meaning, and its measurement is the precision of the mapping.

At this point, I concede. Knuth was right, as always; I cannot avoid using the word "knowledge". Knowledge defines the space in which data quality can be interpreted. When you say "this is high-quality data", you mean it fits your use case with respect to your expectations and based on your knowledge about the information it carries or represents.

3. Challenges and what can be done?

Applying the principles explained earlier, we can assess data behavior and determine the best approach to ensure its quality based on how solid and crystallized the underlying knowledge is, and how well-defined, understood, and agreed upon the data's meaning (and consequently its use) is by all parties involved. While I've mostly dealt with financial data, which is moderately ambiguous, let me provide examples of different data behaviors to illustrate what I mean.

Consider geolocational/geospatial data used to measure temperatures. In this case, you're fortunate as your data is almost 100% unambiguous. This clarity stems from the long history of cartography, navigation, physics, and meteorology, which have evolved alongside humanity. The concept of location on Earth is exact and well-understood. Temperature is also well-defined, with three widely accepted standards developed over centuries.

Global navigation satellite systems speak the same language as anyone wanting to identify a position on Earth's surface. The mutual agreement on how we identify locations using coordinates is uniformly used and accepted. You can always verify if a position is valid, have reasonable expectations about values, and deal with a simple type of error: you're either right or wrong about the temperature at a specific point and time. It's almost unambiguous.

However, you might encounter problems when upper management fails to understand that your data is "geo"spatial and attempts to sell the product for recording and processing temperatures in the solar system or the Milky Way, not just Earth. Suddenly, your location information loses meaning, as we have a much less developed system for referencing points in the universe.

In such a scenario, you'd need to consult with the client to understand their methodology for defining points in space (and possibly time) and likely determine what precision and units they use for temperature measurements.

Now, consider working with countries. This concept is less well-defined than temperature or Earth location, but it still has a commonly accepted meaning. If you want to know what countries exist in the world, you can obtain fairly "good quality data" that likely suits your purposes, primarily because everyone knows what a country is, right?

That is, until you want to organize Olympics, convene a UN assembly, or penetrate the Chinese market with global products, forgetting Taiwan's complex "situation". Things invariably become messier as requirements become more specific and unique, or when they're not universally understood, leaving room for differing interpretations. As you lose universal understanding and universal knowledge and drill down to specifics, you lose solid ground and must adjust your transferable, generic knowledge to case-specific knowledge.

Fortunately, "financial data" is very diverse, warranting a whole blog post to explore its intricacies. I say fortunately because nearly a decade ago, I was tasked with writing client-facing "quality assurance guidelines" detailing our efforts to ensure data quality. Since we were processing various types of content with different behaviors, I could think and write about it holistically. I loved the document for what I could include and all the thoughts that went into it, and I hated it for what I wasn't allowed to say.

The document outlined a conceptual framework rather than exact validation rules. It presented five steps across three categories that everyone should apply to data before claiming any quality standard. While some might seem trivial, all have significant implications. These steps build upon each other, and none can be skipped.

Existence and Staleness

Existence: The first aspect of data quality to check is whether you have data at all. Did you receive today's prices? Do you have the case number record for the incident? Did you receive or send out the notification for the next general assembly? Non-existent data can be expected or unexpected. Knowing if something should exist is actually a complex problem. To do it right, you need to know and be certain about what you expect.

You should have an understanding of when a data feed should publish. If you don't receive any data, it's theoretically impossible to determine if your understanding of the publication calendar was wrong, if you expected content and received none, or if the provider made a mistake in communicating or following their publication calendar. This cannot be assessed by looking at the data alone; you'll need to consult with the vendor to align your expectations or have them fix their system. The check for content existence isn't defined by the content itself, but by the knowledge about it. Quality assessment is driven by the content's behavior in relation to your understanding.

Consider instrument/asset prices. You want to know if you didn't get new prices because of a stock market holiday (or a country holiday? Are they the same? Can you have a price even if the stock market was closed? What if the price is calculated by a model and not the result of a trade?), a vendor error, a special market event, or a process error. Or is it a misunderstanding where you expected to receive new prices, but the vendor never planned to send them?

Sorting out these questions and building the knowledge (or content expertise) to efficiently capture information from the data is what ensures its quality. The quality assurance effort isn't about building a system that sends an email if something is null. Rather, it's about knowing, recording, and consistently applying whether something should or should not be null.

Staleness is closely related to null/non-existent data, with minor nuances. It can be considered as a hacked/faked/patched non-existence in time. Many systems handle non-existent data by filling gaps with the last known data. If the error introduced is small enough, having slightly incorrect data may be more valuable to clients than having no data at all.

For instance, using a stale credit rating to define a single asset's spread in the context of a whole portfolio can be better than having no spread for the asset. However, if your business model revolves around trading securities that have just changed credit ratings, staleness becomes unacceptable. In this case, you return to the existence question: how do you know if a "new" rating should exist or not?

Whether staleness is acceptable depends on your use case and its sensitivity to non-updated content, as well as its impact on results. When calculating a market value for a portfolio position, if you lack new prices for one asset but the rest are updated, you can likely use the previous day's price in calculating a portfolio weighting scheme for aggregation. This introduces a small error, but the overall weighting scheme will likely remain representative enough not to impair the usability of aggregated values.

However, if you lack return data for a day, you simply can't roll forward the previous day's return for your portfolio return calculation. It's probably better to assume the missing return is zero or even null. Except, perhaps, when calculating return volatility for each asset - in that case, rolling it forward might introduce less error than assuming it's null.

These hypotheticals and everything described about data quality checks are arbitrary decisions that define what quality means, rather than the quality of the content itself.

Now that you've checked if something exists when it should, and if it's changing when it should, let's move on to the next step.

Sanity and Accuracy 

Sanity refers to whether the data is reasonable compared to a general understanding of similar contents and concepts. It involves checking if existing, non-stale data makes sense, or if what the data represents is even possible. In the geospatial temperature data example, sanity checks would ensure that geocoordinates are valid and temperatures aren't over 200°C or under -50°C. These are further arbitrary choices based on our generic expectations about the content.

When receiving price data, for fixed income securities typically quoted as a percentage of par value, you might assume prices never exceed 250%. However, you can't make the same assumption for equity prices quoted in currency units. Caution is also needed with fixed income instruments not priced as percentages, like many convertibles.

Let's say you're also receiving terms and conditions data. It's reasonable to assume you need an underlying instrument for a convertible bond, or a specific call schedule if the bond is callable and the call type isn't American. Sanity validation includes these self-contained consistency checks.

But is it truly a quality problem if you don't know a convertible bond's underlying asset? If you're simply enumerating instruments and classifying them, knowing that a bond is convertible might suffice. However, if you're performing valuation or assessing risk, not knowing the underlying asset is a showstopper. The definition of a quality problem depends on your use case and expectations.

Sanity can also be assessed by comparing new behavior to previous patterns. For instance, if a price hasn't changed by more than 5% daily over the past year, a sudden 500% daily change is likely a data error that should be flagged by a quality check. Generally, whenever you encounter something in the data that makes you think, "This doesn't make any sense," you've probably identified a baseline for a quality check that falls into the "sanity" category.

However, if upon further investigation, the seemingly nonsensical data does make sense, you may have just expanded your understanding of the data feed or the real-world facts it aims to capture. This indicates that your initial understanding was incomplete or incorrect. Here is an example: 

Once, I was loading mutual fund portfolios from a major provider when a client complained about a fund's composition. It had a large cash component, which they argued was incorrect. Given that the client was the actual fund manager, I had little ground to argue that our data was correct and that we performed quality assurance.

After several exchanges, we discovered that the data provider occasionally used SEC filings to populate their content when fund managers failed to submit holdings directly. SEC regulations sometimes require fund management companies to allocate provisions to individual funds and represent cash offsets for provisioning in portfolios with short positions or derivatives exceeding certain thresholds or time periods. This occurs despite provisioning happening at the company level, not at the fund manager or fund level.

After informing the client and convincing them to directly expose their holdings to our provider promptly, the problem was resolved. The client's fund was correctly represented, the provider had richer and more accurate content, and I felt I'd done a good job - a win-win-win situation.

Everyone was satisfied except my management, who asked: "How was this quality issue not caught by our processes?" and "What are you planning to do to prevent such issues in the future?" I tried to explain our options and why this was more an interpretation issue than a quality issue, but they wanted a trackable Jira ticket, pretending my team would address this systematically.

My argument that we couldn't differentiate between a true cash position and a technical position for regulatory compliance fell on deaf ears. I couldn't explain that such validations would exceed our committed "basic sanity" checks, referencing the "general quality assurance guidelines" I'd written, which they likely never read.

The general understanding of fund representation isn't enough to make this cash position distinction. Processing fund flows with specific information about tax and fee structures, coupon and dividend cash flows, and precise prices could potentially allow replication of asset under management figures for comparison with official published figures. However, this would require significant effort and more precise data than we had.

Another option would be comparing data from multiple feeds including the same fund, but with a single feed containing only position information, our options were limited.

Despite solving the client's problem, improving vendor interpretations, and enhancing our service level and client experience, I couldn't produce a Jira ticket. Management suggested I should have negotiated with the vendor to indicate which funds were based on SEC filings versus self-submissions. I knew the vendor wouldn't do this for various reasons, half of them legal, but that's another story about the realities of the data business and why you should always think in terms of "Your Data," "My Data," "Their Data" before even starting to type df = pd.DataFrame or select * from)

Accuracy means that the data is true, valid, and precise. Unlike sanity checks, accuracy doesn't merely validate something in a generic context or assess reasonability. It doesn't ask if something is possible based on our understanding, but rather if it is correct based on all other data we're aware of. (In this context, correctness doesn't refer to fitness for purpose, but rather that everyone and every attempt to replicate agrees on what it is.)

While sanity checks can validate if a self-contained data object has no internal consistency problems (such as ensuring a market value is a position multiplied by its price) or if the data aligns with our general expectations, accuracy defines very specific expectations. For example, accuracy might involve validating a price from multiple sources; if many vendors agree on a price, it's likely accurate. Similarly, accuracy checks might confirm that a company's market value in a market-cap-weighted benchmark matches its market capitalization, and so on.

When I attempt to identify outliers based on assumptions derived from past experiences or general understanding, I'm dealing with sanity or reasonableness. For instance, a price jumping more than tenfold might be deemed unreasonable.

However, if my outlier detection validates against market movements and I form assumptions based on changes in other data points or publications and their potential impact on the data point under investigation, I'm addressing accuracy.

In this quality assurance landscape—at least in my perspective—we can think of sanity as endogenous validation against generic understanding. Accuracy, on the other hand, can be viewed as exogenous validation against other specific information at our disposal.

Integration

At this point, we have data (existence), it's fresh (staleness), it makes sense based on our general knowledge (sanity), and it looks correct based on other specific information we have (accuracy). Now we try to use it.

To use the data, we need to integrate it. This involves mapping it to our objects, loading it to an accessible location, and ensuring, in a holistic way, that the data aligns with the use case and all other information the use case requires.

Mimicking end-user use cases and eventual usage in data quality assurance offers two major advantages:

  1. It provides a clear picture of the true client experience. Clients don't care about "what" data is wrong; they care if their reports are wrong. This approach nurtures client-centricity.

  2. If you can set up an end-user specific use case for your data and it works for you, you can always argue that the problem isn't with the data. If it turns out to still be a data problem, you'll have a much better understanding of "why" it's a problem. This comes from talking to the client and understanding how it's possible that the data works for you but not for them. Or, more likely based on my experience, you'll discover that the client is trying to use the content in a context where functionality doesn't work, or they're attempting something with the content that wasn't previously considered. Ultimately, this process nurtures knowledge alignment.

If you deliver portfolios with positions in local currency terms and perform translations using updated foreign exchange (FX) rates, but these FX rates are missing in the product or functionality where you're trying to use your local-term portfolio, your data loses coherence for the client. Your results will be incorrect. The quality of your data heavily depends on every other data point utilized in a given use case.

For instance, if your country metadata fails to reflect that Slovenia has joined the Eurozone, it doesn't matter if your sovereign bond feed accurately represents a bond's currency. At some point, when ensuring your data's quality, you need to be certain that all other elements required to interpret your data are available. Otherwise, you cannot guarantee that your data is correct.

It's important to note that "everything else" also encompasses your users' knowledge about how to interpret your content, as much as it does other data points. The quality of your data is not just about the data itself, but also about how it interfaces with other information and how it's understood and used by your clients.

Here are the parts I wasn't allowed to include, and why the integration step was reduced to "availability in the product" in the document. My argument about the importance of integration is based on two key concepts:

  1. Distributed causality

  2. The consequent unavoidability of end-to-end paradigm in testing

Distributed causality means that "Small variations of the initial condition of a nonlinear dynamical system may produce large variations in the long-term behavior of the system." This concept was neatly summarized by Hungarian movie director Zoltan Fabry: "Any excellent chicken broth can be ruined with a little piece of excrement." Charlie Munger expressed a similar sentiment: "If you mix raisins with turds, they're still turds."

When discussing Root Cause Analysis (RCA) - beloved by management - we strongly assume direct causality, believing we can identify a specific root cause, preferably within an actionable contextual framework. Management needs specific root causes because, in their mind, distributed causality isn't actionable. Addressing distributed causality requires first understanding and potentially changing system foundations, group cultures regarding process setup, and the mindset of both the workforce and system architects. These changes are hard to measure, track, and present, and tend to be longer processes than what can be showcased within a business year.

Management asks: Why haven't the reports completed? Because the report generator queue handler was stuck. Why was the queue manager stuck? Because of a network patch and lost connectivity. Why was there a network patch? Because of IT security, and so on, usually arriving at "human error" or "process error."

The "5 Whys" RCA methodology reminds me of Hungarian writer Eva Ancsel, who once said: "The 'why' and 'for what reasons' are very childish questions of low importance. What's really important is why and for what reasons we're asking them."

A human inefficiently designing an error-prone process isn't part of the RCA. The issue will be classified as a process error, so someone will "fix" the process, but not address the human who - for whatever reason - designed and built an error-prone process. A manager making organizational changes where poorly understood functions are dropped, leading to evaporation of institutional knowledge over time and resulting in inefficient monitoring systems, will be represented as either "process" or "human" error in the RCA. The RCA won't call out wrong decisions on organizational changes from years prior or missing institutional knowledge, but will point to shortcomings in the monitoring system. While factually true, is this really the root cause? And if it is, what can be done about it? Without understanding the organizational/knowledge challenges, the action item to "improve monitoring" as remediation of the root cause is merely a wish, with no idea of how to implement it.

There's no escaping distributed causality. Every system that utilizes synergies or reaches a certain level of complexity will have unavoidable distributed causality embedded in its nature, its core genome. This single sentence warrants an entire blog post, but I'll save that for later when discussing conceptual frameworks like Cynefin, which aid in thinking about systems and decision-making within them.

In the context of data quality, the only way to address this phenomenon is to avoid dissecting the holistic use case into components and ensuring their "quality" individually. Instead, we must assess its quality - or fitness for purpose - as a whole, within the context of the use case or purpose.

In my opinion, the way to achieve this is to rethink our production processes and consider quality assurance as an integral part of production in a paradigm called end-to-end production cycles.

4. Production process integrated quality assurance, the end-to-end (E2E) paradigm

End-to-end paradigm for quality assurance in production processes means the process doesn't conclude with product creation, but with its first valid usage. While you can and should have checkpoints and basic validations at various stages of your production pipeline, ultimately your quality assessment is a function of usability. The impact of an incident is the level of the degradation in the usability, and not some obscure metrics that does not reflect the severity or actual headache the problem has caused. And only way to ensure content usability is to attempt to use it.

In financial data, for example, you can't argue that your FX rates are correct without trying to use them in a report. If the report results align with your expectations, you can argue that your FX rates are likely correct. If you have measures or monitoring showing that FX rates were loaded, aren't stale, have sensible values, align with most vendors' publications, were loaded and made available, AND the client report works with them, then your FX rates can be considered correct.

Replicating every use case and mimicking every client behavior isn't feasible, but you can still do two things:

  1. Define hotspots: These are specific client use cases with well-defined outcomes, complex enough to use multiple content and functionality, where the outcome clearly signals if something is wrong. Hotspots are digital (0/1), restrictive by nature with hard expectations, and reactive. You don't know what's wrong, you just know something is wrong, with low or zero false positive signals.

  2. Create measures (and not metrics): These are overall holistic numbers about the system without specific expectations. They're always analog; you observe the numbers but there are no alerts or rules, and you don't have strong expectations for them. Measures help you understand what might have gone awry when your hotspots are triggered.

The two approaches complement each other. A hotspot could be: taking a factor breakdown of a portfolio that replicates a US index. If non-US factors appear in the report, something is wrong. Your measures tell you how many countries were updated in your universe, how many FX rates were populated daily, or how many factor exposures were loaded.

When assessing a hotspot alert, you can refer back to your measures. When the alert fires, you need to consider which systems and content might impact the outcome of your check, and start examining your measures to find an explanation. You break down the complex report and start checking the components and their measures one by one.

These measures aren't KPIs or metrics, and you should never set expectations or targets for them. Measures are a valuable source for later analysis; correlating hotspot results with measures is an effective way to learn about system behavior and create a baseline for improvement. However, this doesn't mean that your measures should have targets or that you should have any expectations about them.

5. Two of my favorites stories about quality assurance 

First story: The Lightbulbs in the US, and the Misunderstanding of Quality Assurance Agreement

While Edison patented the lightbulb in the late 1800s, the US faced significant challenges in scaling up the production of reliable bulbs until the mid-20th century. The US production's biggest challenge was ensuring quality that aligned with designed obsolescence (the Phoebus cartel agreements weren't helping), while still producing functional lightbulbs.

When a US company approached a Japanese manufacturer to import their product, they phrased the contract as "no more than 3% of the delivered product are defective." When the first shipments arrived, the US counterpart was surprised. Next to the large boxes of working lightbulbs, the Japanese company also delivered a smaller box with non-working bulbs. The small box always contained 3% of the total shipment, while the large one contained only working lightbulbs.

While the US company was thinking in terms of an error rate for the final product, the Japanese manufacturer couldn't even interpret what "error rate" meant. They always checked every bulb and never sold any that weren't working. They obviously had faulty bulbs, but these were caught in the manufacturing process by testing each lightbulb individually. They didn't question the contract; if the client wanted to see non-functioning lightbulbs, they could send those too - no more than 3% of the total shipment, as per the contract.

Japan was pioneering quality assurance. 5S, 7M, 7W (all the Kaizen), XYZ, Six Sigma, Two Circles, and so on - the management science part is heavily documented as it was groundbreaking for many US managers that things could be done this way. This story is a textbook example highlighting the importance of end-to-end testing, focusing on use cases and expectations, embedding quality assurance in the production process, and the fundamental misunderstanding that can occur when two parties think differently about quality.

Second story: The Toothpaste Packaging Plant Anecdote - Overengineering and Not Solving Issues Where It's Most Efficient

Legend has it that a packaging plant putting toothpaste into boxes received multiple complaints about empty boxes. The machine sliding toothpaste into boxes wasn't working properly, frustrating customers. Management decided to find a solution to ensure quality.

They hired engineers who reasoned: If a box is empty, it must be lighter. They introduced a scale on the production line that stopped production when it detected an empty box, preventing its shipment. Someone had to remove the empty box before production automatically restarted.

The new system was deemed a success. The engineers and CEO were satisfied, the immediate danger of client cancellations was averted, and packages were always 100% correct. Two quarters later, to escalate the malfunction to the packaging machine manufacturer, the company requested statistics on how often the scale caught errors.

To their surprise, after the first week when the QA system fired a few times, the number was consistently zero. They visited the factory, finding it unlikely that the packaging machine stopped misfiring just as the new QA system was introduced.

At the factory, they discovered large fans placed beside the assembly lines, just before the scale. These fans were blowing empty boxes off the line before they reached the scale. When management questioned this and lectured about interfering with statistics, the line supervisor explained their frustration: After the scale's introduction, they had to manually remove empty boxes each time the line stopped, which was annoying. They devised this method instead, offering to provide statistics on empty boxes collected after each shift.

Whether true or not, this story offers several takeaways:

  1. Management accurately defined the problem (empty boxes are wrong).

  2. Engineers correctly translated the problem (empty boxes are lighter) and set a good quality assurance target (lighter boxes are wrong).

  3. The overall solution disregarded the actual production process, introducing unwanted halts and manual interactions.

  4. Factory workers, when asked about empty boxes, correctly blamed the packaging machine but felt no need to fix it - it wasn't their problem, and they weren't incentivized to change the situation.

  5. Workers' KPIs and goals focused on safety and smooth production, not quality.

  6. When quality assurance jeopardized their KPIs and created extra work, workers immediately devised an efficient solution - better than any engineer who never spent time on the production line could conceive.

Another lesson: executive KPIs that disregard actual production processes and ignore underlying value streams are not just useless; they can be very misleading. The lingering effects and its devastating consequences of Taylorism in modern corporations, however, is a topic for another time.

item.title: Agile Travelling in Cambodia and Laos
item.content:encoded:
How can you have fun and get massive value out of a trip without having any plan in advance? Travelling with two long time friends.

Prologue

I like travelling. Everybody likes travelling. Dogs, food and travelling are universally accepted as “good” things. But like in many other cases, we do things differently and this is how like I do it, if I have a chance.

The rules

  • Define the very high level goal.

    In our case the goal was to travel through the Indochina peninsula.

    • Arrive to Cambodia, and leave from Laos, use local transportation and make your way through the inland.

    • See, smell, taste everything, talk to everybody, ask every question.

    • Organize everything on the spot, the only goal is to experience as much as possible.

  • Define very specific, tiny “secret missions”.

    These missions don’t need to be achievable, they are rather inspirational or directional. Things that force you to step out from the regular lonely planet “10 things you must do in” framework and corresponding premade commercial offerings. Visiting Angkor Wat when you are in Cambodia is not a real secret mission. Its an obvious mission. These minor, personal goals brought to me numerous adventures in the past, this is how I ate a sandwich in Sandwich, licked a Rembrandt in the Rijks, visited Versailles and got into every museum from zero euro - and listened a two hour long guided tour in Swedish narration about French impressionists, I have slept in the garden of a monastery in Greece on the island of Tha sos, drunk surfed (and puked) in Indonesia and so on and so forth. Sometimes it works out well, sometimes it’s a total failure. The journey matters and not the destination, a cliche much easier to say than to act in its spirit.

    • Because I was travelling with others, the mission was quite easy, checking out an original thai box (kun khmer in cambodia, or muy lao in Laos) gala with the locals

    • Eating Balut

Spoiler, the first one was far too easy, and I could not manage the second one. But the trip was awesome.

Travelling with others

There is a very different dynamic depending on who and how many people you are travelling with. I really like solo travelling, because I feel forced to be open to everything around me. Solo travelling makes you connect, with people, places, stories. And in fact solo traveler does not really exists, you always meet with other travelers, shallow connections with people who are like you. No strings attached, no high expectations, eternal freedom to leave or stay, no point to fake anything. Beautiful, short and sometimes surprisingly deep friendships with random but somehow similar people.

Travelling in pairs is the most challenging in my opinion, assuming you want to explore and experience new places. Even if you are same-minded, the bondedness of the duo blocks a lot from the outside world. With a travelling partner, most probably you bring a bubble with yourselves, that is very hard to penetrate. Both from inside out and from outside in. This is not applicable to travelling mates you meet on the road, they are just cameos through your journey, but it is still your trip. With a partner though, you discuss everything between yourselves, you are opinionating your partner’s experience with your own perception and vice-versa. In my experience this rather limits than expands how much you can see and understand of your surroundings. Also wroth to mention that you have infinitely higher coordination cost, than travelling alone. Travelling in pairs works if you know each other for a very long time, and preferably even married, or if the purpose of the trip is more to be together and not to be somewhere else, see something different. 

Travelling in a group of 3 is ideal. You have some coordination cost, but normally manageable. The mentioned bubble of a duo is much less limiting as the given third member always redefines the duos and thus the group itself. If parties are equal, tripolar group dynamic is the healthiest. Like in rock-paper-scissor, or with Zerg-Marine-Protos. Three interacting bodies with non-transitive properties yields good things.

Any group bigger than 3 people is a hit and miss, and the outcome mostly driven by how the group organizes itself into smaller units. For group size over 4-5 dedicated (or at least self-volunteered and accepted) coordinator is needed, pre-approved plans should be on the table, it is a little bit different show.

Preparation

Not having a detailed execution plan does not mean you do not need to prepare. In practice, you should know if you need any vaccines and what are the possible health hazards, what visas you might need and how you can obtain them. Knowing local climate at the time of the year is more than helpful. This you will not have influence on, but you will need to manage somehow.

In a broader perspective, having some understanding of the history, language, government system, public safety, religious background, economy and level of development will help you through the trip. How much money I should bring overall, and how much money I should have with me during the day.

In general for preparation you want consider two things:

  • Look up those things, that must be acted upon before the trip. These things will not change whatever decision you make. If the rainy season is there, you need a raincoat, it is irrelevant how you approach the problem of the “rain”. If you need vaccine or visa otherwise you are not allowed to enter the country, it does matter if you believe in vaccines or visas or not.

  • Research target region with the eye of a historian and an economist. Having historical (current or ancient) facts piled up in your head creates a mind map with landmarks you can use to anchor your experiences on. Knowing a little about the local economy will help you avoid scams.

Cambodia and Laos

Laos

Capital: Vientiane

Ethnic and religion: mixed Lao (60%) and others, mixed Buddhist (60%) and other Thai local religions (which are close to different ways of Hinduism)

Population: 8 Mill

GDP/Capita: 9,700$

Cambodia

Capital : Phnom Penh

Ethnic and religion: dominant Khmer / Buddhist (90%+)

Population: 17 Mill

GDP/Capita: 6,500$

item.title: Stop - Saying - Innovation!
item.content:encoded:
“Beware of Greeks bearing innovation”

What lead me here?

We are living in the society of the spectacle, at the end of the history, with some concerns about the future of freedom. In this mass- and social-media dominated, buzz-word heavy, hype-cycle flavored world, cognitive saturation ( or rather semantic satiation) more often than not shifts grotesquely the true meaning of words, and with increasing pace builds connotations mostly coloring the original usage by positive attitudes and desires, and remove or ignore important characteristics of the original meanings or concepts. This phenomenon can be captured on the most spectacular level within corporations, who are piggy-backing - mostly - the English language and extends/transforms the original meanings of words and start to use them in their own way like a dialect or a jargon. I could tell numerous examples, but it would take a lot to explain them, for the very exact reason mentioned above, they are very specific to companies. But in a broader context there are also quite a lot of examples, and on the top of my list there is : “innovation” (closely followed by “strategic”, but this writing is not about that.) 

I hear this word thrown around all the time, especially in internal/external leadership communications of corporations. It has a strong positive connotation, and in most of the cases the usage of the word is companies’ attempt is to not to say anything tangible, but to express some general feeling of a better future, a promise of growth, new things, new markets, new methods, more efficiency … at the and of the day, more money. But it’s a “feel-good” promise and nothing more in most of the cases, even if it wants to look more than that by attaching itself to something evidently crucial.  

I simply despise this, especially because I do believe innovation is an important thing, and would worth to talk about it. But if the word itself slides into the domain of these twisted, semantically satiated concepts, there is a threat that the original ideas and their key attributes gets forgotten and looses their inherent value. 

What is innovation? What does it mean? Dissect the nature of it, and by putting the management hat on,  investigate what a company can actually do if they would take innovation seriously besides trying to virtue signal to markets to inflate their stock prices.

What is innovation?

Innovation has no objective properties and thus cannot be unambiguously defined. The word itself is rooted in Latin, meaning "made into something new" or "altered." Innovation differs from invention in both etymology and meaning. While invention produces something entirely new, addresses existing problems, and has tangible outcomes, innovation builds upon existing entities or processes by rearranging, optimizing, or using them in novel ways.

Innovation emerges through trial and error when we improve existing processes, while invention occurs when we pursue new solutions to unexplored problems. Innovation focuses on improving applicability and progression of existing things, whereas invention creates entirely new solutions that didn't exist before.

When I have hard time to get a grasp on a concept, I try to define the opposite of it. It is a good epistemological tool. So what could be the opposite of innovation?

The opposite of innovation is best practice.

Best practice means following established, proven methods that consistently deliver optimal results with minimal risk, or rather the risks are identified and their mitigation is more known than not. Innovation, by contrast, involves uncertainty: outcomes are unpredictable, superior results aren't guaranteed, and risks are inherent when trying new approaches. More unknown unknowns, as Donald Rumsfeld - famous American philosopher - put it.

Innovation can only be identified in retrospect. While one can plan to follow best practices, it's impossible to declare something innovative beforehand. Innovation becomes evident only after a new approach consistently outperforms previous best practices and proves reproducible. This follows Rumsfeld's logic: the risks of "unknown unknowns" of innivation gradually transform into "known unknowns" and finally into "known knowns" of best practices with time.

( I need to make a remark about the Zizekian perspective too, the "unknown knowns" - or the ideology of innovation - represents the theatrical fetishization of disruptive practices. This creates an illusion for the working class, who, while only they can actually innovate, unknowingly participate in their own exploitation through the ideology of innovation. Though the ideology of innovation presents itself as non-ideological, the constant push for pseudo-innovation serves merely as another capitalist spectacle reinforcing existing power structures. Like when the boss order people to be more innovative, dedicate time for innovation and plan for the next quarter how many innovations they should have with tangible impact - “we will increase operational efficiency through technology and innovation with 30%” - and so on and so forth. David Graber said once, that your progress in a modern organization or company is not a function of meritocracy, but how much you are able to align to the lie that your progress in a modern organization or company is a function of meritocracy. Something very similar happens with innovation, the company does not want you to be actually innovative, and for a good reason, they don’t want you take risks and do everything differently in the hope of better outcome every time. On the contrary, they want you to align to the lie that the company is innovative, but they want consistent, optimal outcome with minimal unknown unknowns).

item.title: Lingering Taylorism and its devastating effects in modern corporations
item.excerpt:encoded: Taylor coined the term “manager”. Actually he did not, Fayol and Follett did so but nobody cares about them. Nevertheless, Taylor's impact on management practices is immense. He introduced the concept of "management by metrics" and applied the scientific method to management, which had a significant influence on the rapid growth of factory output during the industrialization era. It's unfortunate that we no longer live in the late 1800s, as Taylor's ideas were particularly well-suited to that time period. How the principles of Taylorism can be applied in a modern organization that has high value added production streams, highly educated workforce and expected to innovate, disrupt, create? It cannot, let’s see why.

item.title: CV
item.content:encoded:
Jani Szlatenyi

Tech-savvy Economist | Data Engineering & Analytics Lead | Technology Management

El Cerrito, CA 94530  

(909) 343-3108 | jani@szlatenyi.net | www.szlatenyi.net

Summary

Experienced technology and data professional with a strong background in economics, risk and performance analytics, and financial technology. Over 15 years of experience contributing to innovation and business growth in the financial sector, with progressively increasing responsibilities. Strong contributor to MSCI's remarkable growth over the past 15 years, as the company expanded its workforce by over 550% and grew its market capitalization to more than $40 billion. During this period, the analytics business experienced more than tenfold growth.

Instrumental in building and developing global teams, executing on location and technology strategy, building out global presence in both data operations and project work, including direct support for high-profile clients. Deep expertise in financial markets data and technical vendor management, analytics, and risk management systems. item.title: Structural Malignance - J28244
item.content:encoded:
I’m not taking sides, I don’t think there is morality in war, I don’t think conflicts - military or not - are epic battles of good and evil.
But there is a level of evil and level of heroic effort and competence as well I feel I have to call out. The story of the Azeri Embraer 190 disaster shows examples of both.

On December 25th, Flight J28244 carrying 62 passengers departed from Baku en route to Grozny but never reached its destination. At 8:16 AM local time, as the aircraft began its descent toward Grozny airport, it was struck by a Pantsir air defense missile system. At the time, Grozny was experiencing Ukrainian drone attacks.

According to the telegram channel VCsK-OGPU, Russian air defense initiated the "KOVER" protocol at 8:17 AM - a series of measures designed to protect airspace over critical infrastructure, airports, and cities. Civilian air traffic control was notified at 8:21 AM, one minute and six minutes respectively after the civilian aircraft was hit.

After sustaining damage, the aircraft repeatedly requested landing permission, but was denied by every Russian airport in the region, despite there being numerous facilities available. All rejections cited "bad weather" as the reason. This explanation appears questionable, particularly since Grozny airport had initially authorized the landing approach, which would not have occurred if weather conditions were severely compromised. Russian air traffic control ultimately directed the plane to cross the Caspian Sea and attempt landing in Aktau, Kazakhstan.

The suggested flight path across the Caspian Sea was highly problematic for several reasons. Commercial aircraft are not fueled to their maximum capacity, but rather based on their planned route distance. This plane barely had sufficient fuel for a sea crossing, and more critically, it had sustained significant damage. Despite official reports attributing the damage to a bird strike, the aircraft was actually hit by a missile. With compromised navigation and control systems (and according to unverified sources, further electronic jamming during the attempted sea crossing), directing the aircraft over open water appears to have had sinister implications.

While the initial strike appears to have been accidental - likely due to incompetence, misidentification, or target confusion (for god’s sake, how can you mix up this with this) - the subsequent handling of the incident suggests deliberate malice. The most plausible explanation for directing a damaged aircraft over open water was to ensure any evidence of shooting down a civilian aircraft would be lost at sea.

The Embraer 190, a modern aircraft comparable to the DC-9 or B-747, is known for its robust construction. Captain Igor Ksnyaki, with over 10,000 flight hours of experience, likely immediately understood both what had happened and the implications of the Russian authorities' instructions. After being denied landing permission at multiple airports (including Rostov, which the pilot contacted in a desperate attempt to avoid crossing open water), the crew demonstrated remarkable skill.

With disabled navigation and hydraulic systems, and growing fuel concerns, the pilots resorted to flying the aircraft like a tank - controlling direction and altitude solely through differential thrust adjustments between the two engines, requiring constant micro-corrections. This improvised technique is clearly visible on the telemetry pictures.

Upon reaching Aktau airspace, the pilot attempted a crash landing but had to abort due to excessive speed. After making another circuit to reduce speed and altitude, the second landing attempt resulted in a crash.

28 people survived.

The broader implications are clear, if unsurprising: While warfare often operates outside normal moral boundaries, any system whose immediate response to malfunction, incident, wrongdoing is to deny, defend, and dispose at any cost reveals itself as fundamentally corrupt, structurally malignant, regardless of whether it is at war or peace.
item.excerpt:encoded: Shooting down civilian airplanes is more than unfortunate. Lying about it and trying to cover it up is not less than sinister.

item.title: Some science news - 2024 Ignobel
item.content:encoded:
The 2024 Ignobel price winners, finally the proofs we all waited for:

  • Anatomy: Scalp hair whorls are more likely to spiral in a counter-clockwise direction in the Southern Hemisphere compared to the Northern.

    Thanks to: Marjolaine Willems, Quentin Hennocq, Sara Tunon de Lara, Nicolas Kogane, Vincent Fleury, Romy Rayssiguier, Juan José Cortés Santander, Roberto Requena, Julien Stirnemann, and Roman Hossein Khonsari.

  • Biology: repeatedly exploding paper bags next to a cat that was standing on the back of a cow and finding that it caused the cow to produce less milk.

    Thanks to: Fordyce Ely and William Petersen

  • Botany: finding that certain plants imitate the leaf shape of nearby plastic plants and concluding that "plant vision" is plausible

    Thanks to: Jacob White and Felipe Yamashita

  • Demography: supercentenarians and extreme age records tend to come from areas with no birth certificates, rampant clerical errors, pension fraud, and short life spans

    Thanks to: Saul Newman

  • Medicine: Fake medicine that induces painful side-effects can be more effective than fake medicine that does not cause painful side-effects

    Thanks to: Lieven Schenk, Tahmine Fadai and Christian Büchel

  • Peace: B. F. Skinner, posthumously awarded for his study on housing live pigeons inside missiles to guide them to their targets

  • Physics: Long running experiment on how dead trout can swim

    Thanks to: James Liao

  • Physiology: several mammals can breathe through their anus.

    Thanks to: Takanori Takebe

  • Probability: A team of 50 researchers, for performing 350,757 experiments to show that when a coin is flipped, it is slightly more likely land on the same side as it started.

Joke aside, I think Shenck Fadai and Buchel’s work on proving that painful placebos are more effective than non painful ones is something can be utilized in corporate environments and management science.
item.excerpt:encoded: ignobel 2024. Did you know that some mammals can breath through their anuses? Now you know.

item.title: Are we happy, Vincent? How about you, Jerome? (Inflation, what else)
item.content:encoded:
The data is out, and inflation has been defeated! No, not just defeated—destroyed! It grew 0.1% less than expected. On a year-on-year basis, before seasonal adjustments (and let me note here that finalized inflation figures tend to come out a year later—this is one of the very few data points that is actually bi-temporal, tri-temporal in some sense), but who cares? Details don't matter, only the victory! The numbers are better than we expected, and Daddy Jerome already promised rate cut(s), so now it has to happen! Oh boy, we are happy.

Finally, interest rates can go back to the "normal" close-to-zero rate, or at least start falling consistently, AS THEY SHOULD BE! At least according to all the CEOs and entrepreneurs who've convinced themselves over the last two decades that they're business geniuses. They believe their companies "exceptional growth" has nothing to do with the little fact that yields are negative and money is free (or at least it will always be cheaper to borrow in the future than it is now). No, it's only due to their relentless innovation, exceptional leadership abilities, and business knowledge, of course. And surely all the junior analysts are also excited, having been socialized in an economic ecosystem where money was technically free.

The best interest definition I've seen over the years: Interest is the cost of allocating money in time. This is deep and has many implications. A zero-interest environment has nothing to promise for the future. It tells you that the money you can get today (from the future) has no cost, so future money is worth the same as current money, or even less. It means there's no growth. Add inflation, and a zero-interest environment tells you: No growth, the top of the world is flat. We can put concrete (or plastic trash) molehills on top of it, but it's still flat.

There are various theories about the origin of interest. I have my favorites, but one thing is certain: it's an ancient concept. Actually, two things are certain: it's an ancient concept, and every major religion throughout human history has prohibited or at least condemned its application in the way money markets and central banks view it today. How capitalism looks at it, I might say. If you consider religion as a sort of proxy for human wisdom, maybe the "don't mess with interest rates" could be as universal a rule for building and maintaining prosperous societies as not stealing, cheating, killing, or lying. I'm not a huge fan of religions, but I still believe:

Religion > Modern Money Making Mechanism

I've written it before: central bank actions tend to impact the real economy on a 12-24 month timeframe. The fact that the year-to-year June-July inflation data is smaller than expected (smaller by less than the normal seasonal and later adjustments, by the way) is only a long-awaited justification for rate cuts. But the Fed is desperate, as the "activist treasury" technically started to continue quantitative easing (QE) when the Fed started to tighten (tighten = not printing money in the basement to go out and buy stuff anymore). Accordingly, the treasury started to shift the short-term yields. We see similar actions in European markets, where governments have started to step up as guarantors behind loan granting. I read somewhere (I can't find the source at the moment) that over 80% of corporate debt originated in the last 5 years is backed by the government. The US treasury asset buying and the Italian government loan guarantees end up with the same result: messing with the yield curves behind the central banks' backs. Like drug addicts finding a way to scam their dealers by faking supply/demand or … I don’t know what is the analogy of a credit spread in the drug businesses...

I think there's quite a big slowdown in the economy and a lot of inflated statements and profound lies about it. If Powell starts cutting in September that will temporarily bring some ease but not for long, and if the US goes through a funny election with a rather entertaining but more painful outcome, 2025 could be the year when we see something drastically change and possible corrections or even bigger restructuring occur. (oh, by the way, I read some parts of “the project”, not as scary as it is pictured, but there are some steep statements or ideas in it, for example to rethink the FED’s mandates )

But I've been saying this for half a decade now or more, so another two things are certain here: I've always been wrong about it before, and eventually, I will be right.

In the meantime, join in the celebration, and hope for the fat Santa Claus rally.
