item.title: CMBS - post covid - pre-collapse - has the world ended yet?
item.content:encoded:
Sidenote: I love the YouTube algorithm and the fearmongering videos, as I was looking at the latest news on the topic, the system started to flood me with videos like “It’s official, the CMBS crash had begun”, “GFC2.0!?!?”, and so on. Do I think there are some challenges piling up in Commercial Mortgage Back Securities? Yes. Will this crash the world economy? Maybe, most probably not. Do I think a random dude on YouTube will give you deep insight about what is happening on the market? Definitely not. (Neither in a random blog, reminder to self, put a disclaimer somewhere. If anybody makes any financial decision based on what I write here, not my problem.)

CMBS - Commercial mortgage back security. In headlines: banks giving out loans, they package (group them together) them based on their assumed risk and other characteristics, and sell it on the market. Usually:

  • half of them are interest only

  • some spread over rate coupon

  • medium to long term debts (weighted average is around 9 years)

The sector is squeezed from every direction. The interest only loans will hit refinancing walls, the interests are raising, and the commercial real estates are heavily underutilized post pandemic. (Ultimate source of data is the trepp database https://apps.trepp.com/crefc/database.html )

Commercial real estates gave extensions for the renters after covid, but still the delinquency rates are raising, occupancy plumets. Converting these commercial buildings to apartments is not easy, some estimates shows that rebuilding an office space to residential is easily 50-70% cost compared to build residential from scratch.

On the other hand the CMBS market is not enormous, roughly 1-2% of the overall fixed income market, ~1 trillion $ over the ~50 trillion $ of bonds or something like that. It’s 90+ rate went from 3.01% to 3.24% in a quarter.  Seasonal adjustments bringing it a little bit lower, so some increase can be captured (which is significantly lower than what I would expect btw.), but overall not great, not terrible. 2008 MBS crisis had ~6.5% default rate, the MBS market was about 7-10 trillion $ that triggered the crisis, so this is one magnitude off roughly. The only troubling thought is that the problematic subprime assets of 2008 can be compared to the CMBS chunk (especially if you think about the interest only payments, where refinancing walls will be hit, they were both around 500 billion $. Due to the trench structure of the MBS securities, this might cause similar cascading effect across CMBSs, Citibank, Wells Fargo, Goldman will take the biggest hits.)

item.title: VIX^ Excitement - Carry, Over?
item.content:encoded:
Japan has been in a phase advantage compared to the world since the 80's - or maybe even earlier. While everybody else is sitting on the edge of their chair waiting for rate cuts and afraid of inflation stickiness, Japan hikes the rates and fears deleveraging-driven deflation, begging for some sticky, low inflation.

Debt is some 280% of the GDP (440% if you ask Ray Dalio). Japan has been cutting rates and implementing QE, then QQE, zero interest rates - yet no inflation, no growth, and an immense debt burden. Nothing worked. Abe or not Abe, an aging, infertile, highly advanced economy with limited natural resources and ~120 million people has kind of maxed out the Japanese economy, and the top of the world is flat.

We should really worry about Japan, not because their problems might spread and cause a global crisis, but because they act as a forecast for the rest of the world economy. Japan's new-age problems started in the late 80's, early 90's, and their situation was identical in nature to the 2008 "global financial crisis". Literature started to call it a "balance sheet recession".

What we see now and in the last decade in Japan is most probably a very realistic playbook for the world economy for the next 20 years or so.

I was looking for some commentary from Richard Koo or Nomura, who argued in 2009-2010 that Japan handled their balance sheet crisis of the 90's successfully, but I couldn't find anything yet. Only Krugman, Krugman always has something to say. I remember his commentary from 2010 because it seemed legit and I agreed with it about Koo's work. He is a smart person, but I rarely have the same reading and first reaction as him. I guess I'm just dumb.

Krugman was pointing out that the saving elasticity is actually also impacted by monetary policy even in a balance sheet recession. This is contrary to Koo, who argued that it's independent (the QE/QQE was the only viable action to take, as per Koo. Koo doesn't seem to like Austrians, only Keynes).

I also remember my stepfather's commentary in 2007-2008, which made a point abundantly clear about problems in Koo's work: There are not only self-fulfilling prophecies in economics, but their opposites too. Sometimes naming a threat is taming a threat. If people expect heavy inflation, recession, or economic headwinds, they might jump the gun and make preemptive investment or consumption decisions, expecting they might not have the chance to act later. If enough people do so, they might avoid a deeper recession because they were afraid of a deeper recession. Life does not have A/B testing, you simply cannot know if your actions or the expectations of the participants about the result of your actions changed the any given system.

A credible threat of inflation might do better for the Japanese economy than any monetary or fiscal action to boost inflation. 

BOJ had to do something though, the situation of the JPY was unsustainable. All the incredibly smart investors, who can compare two percentages with a grim of all-knowing wisdom, but without the slightest f*king clue about their actual risk they run, who found the "free money" of borrowing in zero interest JPY, and investing into a mid-single digit market, greedier ones to the stocks, more conservatives to the bonds has no other option but to liquidate and even eat up losses now on the FX. If they were brave or stupid and made the positions with some hefty leverage, they are in a pickle now. Imagine when you buy on 160 and you have to sell on 140, just because you found a yearly 700 bps spread on the return and you were so happy and excited about it. I guess they never looked at the story of the TRY/ISK in 2008.

Now half of the "summer-end-boredom, pre-election-doldrum" financial analyst regime tries to guess the size of the JPY/USD carry positions. Fearmongers are fearmongering, opportunists look at it as opportunity, and the world goes on. I'd doubt that the JPY/USD carries were over 500 Billion, I'd say it's about a magnitude smaller than the losses CMBS will apparently eat up eventually, and two magnitudes smaller than the residential real estate and corresponding financial issues of China. What we know for sure, the world has not ended yet, but we are getting closer.

But I found this video, and now I watch it again. Artemis capital had really good stuff, it’s a shame they stopped producing them.

item.title: Slava Ukraini!
item.content:encoded:
I'm not taking sides. I believe the Russia-Ukraine war is far more complicated than portraying it as an epic battle of good versus evil, as we often do with complex issues. This doesn't mean I don't have opinions or moral judgments, but I also don't believe in universal morality, so… Ukraine is right, but as Russell pointed out accurately: "the war does not determine who is right, only who is left”. And those writes the history of military conflicts who are left. (as Norm MacDonald said: “It says here in this history book that luckily, the good guys have won every single time. What are the odds?”)

There is, however, a ray of hope to end this devastating war. My opinion was that Ukraine couldn't win this war outright, but that doesn't mean it has to lose it either. The initial blitzkrieg failed, and Russian military strategy switched to bleeding out Ukraine by stretching the frontline and ramping up their war economy. Ukraine was indeed bleeding and had to respond.

The basic concept of this strategy has the following anatomy:

  • The attacker always needs to sacrifice more resources than the defender, and this scales disproportionately. If the defender doubles its forces, the attacker needs to commit more than double their forces to succeed. This disproportion is especially pronounced due to technological advancements in military equipment and the nature of urban warfare. If the defender can concentrate its defense, it has a better chance of resisting the attack.

  • If the attacker separates its forces and breaks down its attacks into small, localized, fast hits instead of large military maneuvers and offensives, it forces the defender to constantly reallocate forces. This is due to the potential threat and lack of intelligence about which incursion might transform into a larger military movement. This approach is costly, tiresome, and still results in losses of military equipment and manpower for the defender.

  • This strategy relies heavily on good logistics in the background, a war economy that scales better than the defender's, and very agile, rapid replanning of actions. The goal is not to take territory, reinforce presence, build bases, and move on, as it would normally be in an offensive like this. Instead, there is only one objective: to spread the defenders as thin as possible and grind them down piece by piece, destroying not just equipment and manpower but also morale.

The only viable reaction to this strategy (besides surrendering, which I fully understand Ukraine doesn't want to do) is a counteroffensive or rather a kind of modern sortie. With a few small to medium counteroffensives, the defender can break the asymmetry of the bleeding-out strategy and force the attacker to react instead of initiate, the context switch cost from attacker to defender in case of a kind of siege is much heavier than the the opposite. This forced reaction is incredibly inconvenient for the attacker, as it disrupts logistics and confuses those trying to coordinate the bleeding-out attacks. It also boosts the eroding morale of the defender.

Heroyam slava! Good job.

item.title: Car manufacturers market corrections
item.content:encoded:
We recently considered buying a car and thoroughly explored electric vehicles (EVs). However, we ultimately chose a V6 truck. For our lifestyle and use cases, an EV wasn't a viable option. I struggle to see how 600 pounds of lithium sitting in my driveway 95% of the time will save the planet. That said, if I had a daily commute, I might have considered an EV more seriously.

EVs are expensive, and I had mild concerns about their stated versus realistic lifespan and range on a single charge, as most manufacturers tend to significantly overestimate these figures. I also had reservations about maintenance, build quality, and the industry's experience with this technology. I suspect I'm not alone in these concerns. (for example Mr. Toyoda is with me in this, and I think he might know a tad more about the industry than I am.)

After the recent reporting season, car manufacturers uniformly experienced a market correction.

When the same sector behaves similarly across continents and markets, I typically don't bother decrypting the sugar-coated statements in individual car manufacturers' quarterly financial reports, only to find the same underlying cause. Instead, I prefer to look at aggregated macro charts from sources like FRED or the World Bank to understand what's happening.

After reviewing these broader trends, I occasionally return to individual company reports and look for:

  1. The level of acknowledgment of obvious underlying causes

  2. The degree of self-reflection hidden in descriptions of the company's current or future focus

  3. Any changes in their reporting methodology (a significant red flag)

Car sales in the US have been stagnant and started to drop in the last quarter.

Inventory is increasing, easy to capture on the Inventory/Sales ratio.

Looking at price levels, inflation in recent years is also evident in various producer price indices. Overall, we're seeing an increasing supply volume at higher prices, coupled with decreasing demand growth, especially in the electric vehicle (EV) sector.

EV research and development is costly, and many companies made substantial investments assuming the EV boom would continue to accelerate. When this exponential growth fails to materialize, but investments have already been made, a market correction occurs.

Meanwhile, a significant underlying battle is unfolding between the US, EU, and China in this sector. It's not just about Trump's or Biden's tariffs (which, interestingly, show a beautiful continuity in foreign trade policy - Americans might want to pay more attention to these similarities rather than differences). Leaders like Ursula von der Leyen and Xi Jinping are also concerned about this topic and bring it up to each other from time to time.

In the medium term, I would be much more worried about the car industry than, say, the CMBS market, though that's also worth examining. (saying this while just looking at the latest Trepp data, and it's quite revealing.)

item.title: Venezuela elections
item.content:encoded:
Venezuela has always been an interesting yet sad case study. Since the discovery of oil in the 1920s, the country has become a textbook example of various issues and how not to manage them. These include state capture, petro-state failure, the disadvantages of an extensive economy, overwhelming propaganda, and totalitarianism.

The situation also provides insight into the complexities and controversies of US foreign policy. It's somewhat ironic when the US government comments on the "democratic crisis" in Venezuela while remaining less vocal about their own historical involvement and manipulation attempts, which may have had a fat contribution to the current situation. Leaders like Gallegos and Perez likely had a more nuanced view on the roots of this "democratic crisis"  than what officials like Pompeo presented time to time.

Venezuela experienced seven coups d'état in the last century. The country has been in technical default since 2017, with government bonds trading at around 20 cents on the dollar. Conservative estimates suggest that over 5 million people have left the country of 30 million, and 80% of the population lives in poverty. Basic goods are inaccessible, and the country suffers from hyperinflation, famine… and US sanctions of course.

Despite these challenges, Maduro managed to maintain power by claiming 51% of the votes - after processing 118% of them I guess.

This situation demonstrates that exporting democracy doesn't always work and perhaps was never truly intended to. The naivety surrounding the resilience of liberal democracies is significant, damaging, and has devastating consequences. While liberal democracy may be a good system or idea, it cannot be implemented and kept stable merely by supporting leaders who makes the pinky promise promise not to abuse their power while offering cheaper natural resources for superpowers who happen to raise concerns about human rights. 

I’ll continue reading "Future of Freedom," as it becomes clear that the challenges facing democracy are complex and multifaceted, and Venezuela has always been an interesting yet sad case study of this.

I’m sure I’ll finish it before the first Tuesday of November…
item.excerpt:encoded: Maduro won the elections in Venezuela.

item.title: Mild concerns about our macro-data
item.content:encoded:
Something is not right with our macro data. “Our numbers are weak”, and does not look realistic to me. Not as unrealistic as https://www.shadowstats.com/ though.

I already mentioned the revolutionary calculation changes on the CPI around the 80’s, and I do believe that the methodology how the CPI is calculated is simply wrong, not representative. But the shadowstats author got a tad confused with annual as year over year, and annualized number of a whole period of time in the difference between the CPI and R-CPI-U. This mistake kind of undermines any credibility of the site unfortunately. Because on the other hand, he is after something, I also find many of our macro data unrealistic.

I’m not the only one apparently though, I found an interesting study where the authors are trying to explain the sentiment index anomaly with alternative macro data. Voices in my head yelling “lead” and “lag” and “fear” and “greed”, but still reading it through because I find the proposition interesting. The sentiment index anomaly is when sentiment index is going down while there is no macro data would imply why the sentiment index goes down. Unemployment is low, inflation is under control, stock prices are going up; “What the long nose is about?” Is it possible that our macro data does not reflect accurately the true state of the economy? Not the perception of the people are wrong about the economy, but rather the numbers are wrong that creates false perception that everything is fine for economists. 

The more I’m trying to make sense out of the numbers, the more I find myself in the side of Fox news, and Heritage foundation and other GOP backed institutions, which makes me feel quite uncomfortable. I do not like that the question of CPI or M2 or interest rates became just like many things overly political, with sides and beliefs and agendas and narratives. But at the end of the day, if E.J. Antony is right, we are in recession, even if the “official” CPI data is applied on some fundamental numbers. And if the numbers are wrong and CPI is underestimated, the “real” real numbers are devastating.

Have the world ended already? Not yet, but getting close.
item.excerpt:encoded: Cannot make sense of the macro data. Maybe macro data does not make any sense.

item.title: Russian-Ukraine War - 2024
item.content:encoded:
The Russia-Ukraine War

I don't take sides; I condemn aggression and believe it's unacceptable to invade one's neighbor. Or not neighbor. Punching each other in the face is not cool, nailing somebody on a cross who points this out also not cool. However, I care about the truth and the real nature of things. I'm tired of propaganda, whether it's Russian, Hungarian, Ukrainian, Chinese, American, Israeli, or Palestinian. Propaganda is propaganda, regardless of its source.

I've noticed something interesting while looking for news about the Russia-Ukraine war:

  1. The most informative site is liveuamap. It lacks narrative and storytelling, instead showing you what happens: reported events and a visual map of the front lines. It tells more, and more accurately, than any news site. These are the facts, the real events of the world (or war).

  2. Most news analyses are incredibly one-sided. However, reasonably objective analysis can be found on YouTube if:

    • The presenter is not a content creator but a professional soldier, intelligence agent, or military analyst.

    • The view count is under 10,000 in the first week, implying that people might find it boring, too detailed, or dry.

I need to make a remark here: I've been a huge fan of Austrian Bundesheer videos from day one. While writing this and checking the linked video, I noticed it has gained quite high popularity over the last two years. I find the comments interesting as well, they are praising the "real information," the "lack of propaganda," and the factual, cold analysis of situations "without any BS." The best comment: "I need an Austrian running all my business presentations”.

In relation to the Ukrainian war, I began reading and watching more about military strategy, finding it fascinating. I was delighted to discover Sarah C.M. Paine on the internet. Her notion of "whales" and "elephants," and how maritime and continental powers have different "genomes" regarding setting up zero-sum positive and zero-sum negative games in military conflicts, fascinates me. This is particularly interesting because I notice similar patterns in other areas too, highlighting how much we are defined by our essence, the fundamental "who we are" question. By the way, Huntington's book is good; I might reread it. I think it's actually better than initially perceived. When I was around 40, I was chatting with an old school friend. We were discussing how a mutual friend, whom we've known for 25 years, was making poor life choices. My friend remarked that it's interesting to see how the attitudes we observed and learned about each other in high school transform into fate as time passes. 

This content is lengthy, more suited to a podcast or book than a video. I played it in the background a couple of weeks ago and noticed that while I couldn't maintain constant focus, I kept being drawn back in because she is entertaining and says interesting things. It truly provides food for thought.

item.title: US Nukes and Sentiment Index
item.content:encoded:
Have the world collapsed yet? - no, but getting there slowly

(cursory look at Bloomberg)

I don't like sentiment analysis. This isn't because I believe investor and consumer decisions are always fully rational. I understand that perception, expectations, conscious/subconscious biases, and the eventual growth of the economy and overall throughput are heavily influenced by individuals' (from consumers to CEOs) personal decisions that aren't rational.

I wrote my thesis about Kahneman (and Tversky), and I firmly believe these irrational processes matter significantly. To clarify my position: Sentiments are important, but I don't think we can adequately interpret the results of a sentiment survey in isolation.

10year - 50 year

There is indeed a decline. However, there has always been a decline, and I don't think the falling sentiment can be attributed to any single specific factor. We're dealing with a confluence of issues: it's an election year, there's ongoing war, we're in a state of perma-media-crisis, we're experiencing post-COVID awakening, inflation remains sticky, and unemployment lingers.

The only aspect I find particularly interesting, and have been pondering more and more, is that the current situation seems somewhat reminiscent of the late 1980s, albeit with numerous differences, of course. Kondratieff's ideas about long-term economic cycles sometimes haunt my dreams.

On more “cheerful” note, headline goes:

US needs more nukes, Biden finally gets that.

No, we don't... Let me put it this way: the quality and capabilities of U.S. presidential candidates and presidents, both as national leaders and as human beings, have shown a certain degradation over the last few cycles. Arguing that Biden "finally gets something" is a very strong statement, but if it were Trump, it would only be fitting as a punchline to a joke. His days have long since passed. But let's say we're talking more about the administration. Still, NO.

Let's note here first: The White House made a clear statement about two weeks ago, focusing on the U.S. nuclear strategy - not as a weapon, but as a holistic industry. We'll discuss that more later, but I think it's important.

Journalists weren't really bothered to differentiate between produced, prepared, or deployed nukes. However, I don't blame them this time. I believe the cabinet members and advisory boards intentionally phrased things vaguely for good reason when they said:

Now, the argument that more nukes would mean more "deterring power" is complete nonsense, one might call it total bullshit. The US currently has about 3,500 nukes, with roughly 1,500 deployed. Russia claims similar numbers, though the truth is uncertain. The point is, besides the US, Russia, France, and the UK, no country has deployed nuclear weapons at all. Any country with a non-deployed arsenal has one or two orders of magnitude fewer weapons than the US. If the volume of nukes correlates with deterring power, why are we so worried about Iran and North Korea?

I can fully agree with stopping nations from becoming nuclear powers. But the sheer number of nukes is largely irrelevant, at least regarding security and military power. The White House official's argument that North Korea is "diversifying and rapidly improving their nuclear capabilities" is questionable. They claim to have 50 nukes, struggle to deliver them, and none are "deployed." So, are you telling me that if the US had 10,000 nukes, or 5,000 deployed instead of 1,500, it would mean greater "deterring power"? I highly doubt it. What does it mean at all - that they'll stop building nukes or won't use them because the US has more? Game theory, mutual destruction, Von Neumann, and so on - it seems to amount to nothing.

In some sense, nukes are very useful - as good business. You pay a lot of money to build a weapon with immense stored and concentrated energy that you're not going to use. After they "expire," or you agree with your bully-buddy not to jeopardize wiping out humanity, you pay a lot of money to "safely" disarm them. Then, the same company converts the fuel cells and sells them for another good sum to nuclear reactors. The START program was a godsend for the nuclear industry!

So, let's summarize the sequence of events and their implications:

  • In early May, Biden administration bans the import of Russian enriched uranium. (yeah, that was a $2 billion annual payment to Russia, despite rhetoric about sanctions and punishing Russia for its actions.)

  • By the end of May, the administration began formulating a revised nuclear strategy, focusing on domestic uranium processing (LEU/HALEU).

  • (Concerned individuals raised concerns as expected)

  • the START program is effectively dead, as Russia unilaterally withdrew in February last year, and it would have ended in 2026 anyway.

  • The START program was a significant underlying asset for the domestic nuclear industry.

Or, to frame it differently:

  • Only those reactors can work that have uranium. The best business is to get uranium is from nuclear arms reduction programs (second best to buy from Russia). But only those arms can be reduced that were produced on the first place. We need more nukes. It makes sense now.

item.title: FED Up!
item.content:encoded:
FED up!

"Officials acknowledge 'modest further progress' of price levels" (I guess it's transitory; it's a long journey).

There are many positive signs in the inflation report. [Jani's interpretation: I really want to cut rates, believe me, I'm looking for reasons.]

What does the Fed need? Jerome: "Good data... data which is good; without good data, we cannot say anything." [This reaches Trumpian heights of rhetoric.]

What will the Fed do? Jerome: "Uhm, we will cut. We might raise and cut later. No, no, just kidding, we will not raise, just cut. Not now, but this year for sure. There will be a cut. Sometimes, seriously, pinky promise. Only one, but there will be. Please don't butcher us; I promise a cut!" [In his head: Oh, for the steel balls of Paul Volcker, these numbers don't let me be the hero I want to be, but I know we screwed this up, just don't know when and how it will backfire.]

The reality is, inflation is not a very strong indicator. Components lag differently, and it doesn't include or fairly represent many factors like housing. M * V = P * Q. After 2008, we pumped up the M (monetary supply). If V (velocity - number of trades) starts going up so economic activity increases, and Q (newly created goods and services' value) cannot catch up, P will rise. P is price.

Just to prove my point about the inadequacy of CPI and how housing costs are calculated, here's a comparison of the Case-Shiller house price index and the "owner equivalent cost of living" index that the Bureau of Labor Statistics introduced in '83. (They argued they don't have good enough data to incorporate house prices correctly - exactly the same argument I heard from Powell half an hour ago. Nihil sub sole novum.)

The Fed's situation is not easy. The economy (if you remove the AI-hyped "magnificent seven") is in recession. Unemployment is hidden, despite the main or core numbers not capturing it. Inflation appears sticky, and the whole economy is experiencing an afterparty effect from zero yields, free money, and Covid relief direct transfers.

If the Fed cuts rates, they relax the monetary system and help the economy slightly; a little inflation might actually help. But if they cut too much, too late, or too early, they risk heavier disruptions and could overheat an already unhealthy economy sitting on asset bubbles of unknown magnitude.

If they raise rates significantly, the economy will not respond well, and underlying non-severe structural problems might turn lethal and highly impactful, especially concerning currency and international reflections. The USD isn't just about the US economy; 88% of all trades are in USD.

The international situation doesn't help either. BRICS nations are pushing to detach from USD-based reserves and trades. Other central banks - quite rightly - see greater dangers in the yuan (or rather renminbi, but let's not delve into that). Meanwhile, gold demand is rapidly increasing among central banks.

Top 3 buyers: China (2x), Poland (1x), Singapore (0.7x) , Czech republic (0.5x). I guess China feels the storm is coming, Poland decided to rather try the European Singapore’s aka. Czech republic’s way and not rushing to join the EUR. All makes sense.

Anyhow, enough monetary policy rage for the morning, I go and listen this, and read some Hayek.

item.title: Some news in the morning
item.content:encoded:
EU elections

Results here!

  • France, Macron catastrophic results, National assembly disbanded, new general elections, far right raises

  • Germany, Scholz worries, far right raises

  • Italy, Meloni is kind of far right already

  • Poland, more centrist, Tusk is doing a good job

  • Austria, far right gain too

  • rest are kind of irrelevant

One outlier? Poland. Poland doesn't have an immigration problem.

My take: We're seeing signs of a perfect storm. The economy isn't at its best, with a silent technical recession occurring. While both France and Germany have traditional and somewhat functional immigration models (France due to its colonial history, Germany with Turkish immigrants), the new immigration waves have been too rapid. More importantly, they've brought in non-secular masses.

Regardless of a place's religious heritage (like Europe's Judeo-Christian background), the stronger differentiator is whether the majority of a population is secularized or not. Europe will need to revisit Karl Popper's ideas and understand that there's no room for tolerating intolerance when it comes to new, non-secularized religious immigrant minorities. Otherwise, they might end up revisiting the work of another Austrian figure.

One odds out? Poland. Poland has no immigration problem.

So, my take: perfect storm signs. Economy is not the best, technical recession is silently happening. While both France and Germany has a traditional and somewhat working immigration model (France due to the colonies, Germany with the Turkish), the new immigration waves were too fast and what’s more important brought non-secular masses. Independently what is the religious heritage of a place, (like Europe is judeo-christian) the stronger differentiator whether the majority of a population is secularized or not. Europe will need to dust off Karl Popper, and understand that there is no room for tolerating intolerance with respect of new non-secularized religious immigrant minorities. Or they will dust off the work of another Austrian dude.

Raspberry PI IPO

Raspberry has always had a special place in my heart. I’m using them since 2012 or 2013 or so. I had mail servers, NAS, bitcoin miner (in 2012, yes. Yes it bugs me. Yes, I did mine and yes, I got pissed because of the halving. No, I have not or not too much,… fuck you), as of now I have 2 raspberry running, one is a display and monitoring backend for security cameras, the other is hosting a local DNS and a DNS cache - Pi-hole, highly recommended.

Limited trading started today, open for public from friday. Initial pricing were okey, they gained some capital, I’m excited to see where the price will land on friday, and I think I will make a small investment on it. Market will crash, and raspberry is a weird mule of business and kind of community service, but I feel I owe them with my support. They were always there when I needed some tiny computer to do some stupid thing, they brought me joy, and their product is awesome.

Apple Intelligence was announced

https://www.apple.com/apple-intelligence/

I have a love-hate relationship with Apple. But if in one thing Apple is good at, it is user experience and AI opens a ton of gates there. They will be able to fit neatly into their walled garden ecosystem the AI tools, some looks exciting, some looks utterly useless (thank you for the real time GenAI based emoji creator, I was not even aware how big gap will be finally filled up in my life, now I understand the void I continuously feel). Only concern that Apple - who gladly picture itself as the big innovator - the first couple generations of their new products tend to be subpar. The idea is there, the marketing even more, but at the end of the day the product is not very very good. Revolutionary, just sucks. I’m not sure just because of the speed of AI developments if they misfire on their AI solution they will get a second chance.

Did the economy collapsed yet?

No, not yet, but getting close.

item.title: AI and the most important 6 second drum loop.
item.content:encoded:
There is a video that I really like. It is about the Amen break, but it tells a much more blatant story about the connection of technology, creation and cultural domains, and intellectual property rights.

For the last 1-2 years or so, everything is about AI, and I cannot help but see the parallels. AI in 2023 is similar to the sampler in the 80's. A new technology that allows you to create something new, based on what was already created before, very rapidly, efficiently, opening new ways of creations. AI was not developed by Peter Zinovieff, a British composer and inventor, but by Geoffrey Hinton, a Canadian cognitive psychologist and computer scientist. It is not a deterministic recorder-disassemble-loop-back cycle machine, but a non-deterministic recorder-disassemble-loop-back predictor machine, in many sense I find them very similar.

In an article some journalist described an LLM as “Jpeg of the internet”, but I think it is more than that. It is not just a “blurry image”, but rather a fractal image. Somebody might see it as blurry, but in fact, you can zoom in and out, find interesting corners, and you can even create something new with it, something that relies on what was done before.

The challenges will be the same as with the sampler and the AI boom is not very far from the electronic music boom of the late 20th century. And most probably the conclusions and outcome will be the same too. Who is the creator, what can be used as a "sample", who owns the IP, who and how can use what got created, etc. Underregulating, will enrich cultural domain and bring a new era of creation, productivity and creativity, that eventually will be consumed by capitalism and commodification, it will get overregulated as business interests start rising, and eventually the legislations and regulations around AI will block any further progress or "consequent free and playful usage" which I consider precursory for creativity.

Just a random thought that I need more time to think about: if AI will be so good, that we cannot identify its product from human made things and more and more things will be produced by AI, how will we be able to train new AI models, avoiding AI generated input. Or is this not a problem at all? Could this lead to some convergence in AI training, and eventually neither us, AI using humans, nor the AI itself will have a chance to understand that this is an elephant who just happened to be swallowed by a snake?
item.excerpt:encoded: The Amen break, thinking about an old video I liked.
